trans-unit.source: Submit Spark jobs remotely using Livy | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Submit Spark jobs remotely using Livy | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use Livy with HDInsight clusters to submit Spark jobs remotely.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use Livy with HDInsight clusters to submit Spark jobs remotely.

trans-unit.source: Submit Spark jobs remotely using Livy with Spark clusters on HDInsight (Linux)
trans-unit.target: Submit Spark jobs remotely using Livy with Spark clusters on HDInsight (Linux)

trans-unit.source: Apache Spark cluster on Azure HDInsight includes Livy, a REST interface for submitting jobs remotely to a Spark cluster from anywhere.
trans-unit.target: Apache Spark cluster on Azure HDInsight includes Livy, a REST interface for submitting jobs remotely to a Spark cluster from anywhere.

trans-unit.source: For detailed documentation, see [Livy](https://github.com/cloudera/hue/tree/master/apps/spark/java#welcome-to-livy-the-rest-spark-server).
trans-unit.target: For detailed documentation, see [Livy](https://github.com/cloudera/hue/tree/master/apps/spark/java#welcome-to-livy-the-rest-spark-server).

trans-unit.source: You can use Livy to run interactive Spark shells or submit batch jobs to be run on Spark.
trans-unit.target: You can use Livy to run interactive Spark shells or submit batch jobs to be run on Spark.

trans-unit.source: This article talks about using Livy to submit batch jobs.
trans-unit.target: This article talks about using Livy to submit batch jobs.

trans-unit.source: The syntax below uses Curl to make REST calls to the Livy endpoint.
trans-unit.target: The syntax below uses Curl to make REST calls to the Livy endpoint.

trans-unit.source: **Prerequisites:**
trans-unit.target: **Prerequisites:**

trans-unit.source: You must have the following:
trans-unit.target: You must have the following:

trans-unit.source: An Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: An Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: See [Get Azure free trial](https://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/videos/get-azure-free-trial-for-testing-hadoop-in-hdinsight/).
trans-unit.target: See [Get Azure free trial](https://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/videos/get-azure-free-trial-for-testing-hadoop-in-hdinsight/).

trans-unit.source: An Apache Spark cluster on HDInsight Linux.
trans-unit.target: An Apache Spark cluster on HDInsight Linux.

trans-unit.source: For instructions, see [Create Apache Spark clusters in Azure HDInsight](hdinsight-apache-spark-jupyter-spark-sql.md).
trans-unit.target: For instructions, see [Create Apache Spark clusters in Azure HDInsight](hdinsight-apache-spark-jupyter-spark-sql.md).

trans-unit.source: Submit a batch job the cluster
trans-unit.target: Submit a batch job the cluster

trans-unit.source: Before you submit a batch job, you must upload the application jar on the cluster storage associated with the cluster.
trans-unit.target: Before you submit a batch job, you must upload the application jar on the cluster storage associated with the cluster.

trans-unit.source: You can use [**AzCopy**](storage/storage-use-azcopy.md), a command line utility, to do so.
trans-unit.target: You can use [**AzCopy**](storage/storage-use-azcopy.md), a command line utility, to do so.

trans-unit.source: There are a lot of other clients you can use to upload data.
trans-unit.target: There are a lot of other clients you can use to upload data.

trans-unit.source: You can find more about them at [Upload data for Hadoop jobs in HDInsight](hdinsight-upload-data.md).
trans-unit.target: You can find more about them at [Upload data for Hadoop jobs in HDInsight](hdinsight-upload-data.md).

trans-unit.target: **Examples**:

trans-unit.source: If the jar file is on the cluster storage (WASB)
trans-unit.target: If the jar file is on the cluster storage (WASB)

trans-unit.source: If the you want to pass the jar filename and the classname as part of an input file (in this example, input.txt)
trans-unit.target: If the you want to pass the jar filename and the classname as part of an input file (in this example, input.txt)

trans-unit.target: **Examples**:

trans-unit.source: Delete a batch job
trans-unit.target: Delete a batch job

trans-unit.source: **Example**:
trans-unit.target: **Example**:

trans-unit.source: Show me an example
trans-unit.target: Show me an example

trans-unit.source: In this section, we look at examples on how to use Livy to submit a Spark application, monitor the progress of the application, and then delete the job.
trans-unit.target: In this section, we look at examples on how to use Livy to submit a Spark application, monitor the progress of the application, and then delete the job.

trans-unit.source: The application we use in this example is the one developed in the article [Create a standalone Scala application and to run on HDInsight Spark cluster](hdinsight-apache-spark-create-standalone-application.md).
trans-unit.target: The application we use in this example is the one developed in the article [Create a standalone Scala application and to run on HDInsight Spark cluster](hdinsight-apache-spark-create-standalone-application.md).

trans-unit.source: The steps below assume the following:
trans-unit.target: The steps below assume the following:

trans-unit.source: You have already copied over the application jar to the storage account associated with the cluster.
trans-unit.target: You have already copied over the application jar to the storage account associated with the cluster.

trans-unit.source: You have CuRL installed on the computer where you are trying these steps.
trans-unit.target: You have CuRL installed on the computer where you are trying these steps.

trans-unit.source: Perform the following steps.
trans-unit.target: Perform the following steps.

trans-unit.source: Let us first verify that Livy is running on the cluster.
trans-unit.target: Let us first verify that Livy is running on the cluster.

trans-unit.source: We can do so by getting a list of running batches.
trans-unit.target: We can do so by getting a list of running batches.

trans-unit.source: If this is the first time you are running a job using Livy, this should return zero.
trans-unit.target: If this is the first time you are running a job using Livy, this should return zero.

trans-unit.source: You should get an output similar to the following:
trans-unit.target: You should get an output similar to the following:

trans-unit.source: Notice how the last line in the output says **total:0**, which suggests no running batches.
trans-unit.target: Notice how the last line in the output says **total:0**, which suggests no running batches.

trans-unit.source: Let us now submit a batch job.
trans-unit.target: Let us now submit a batch job.

trans-unit.source: The snippet below uses an input file (input.txt) to pass the jar name and the class name as parameters.
trans-unit.target: The snippet below uses an input file (input.txt) to pass the jar name and the class name as parameters.

trans-unit.source: This is the recommended approach if you are running these steps from a Windows computer.
trans-unit.target: This is the recommended approach if you are running these steps from a Windows computer.

trans-unit.source: The parameters in the file **input.txt** are defined as follows:
trans-unit.target: The parameters in the file **input.txt** are defined as follows:

trans-unit.source: You should see an output similar to the following:
trans-unit.target: You should see an output similar to the following:

trans-unit.source: Notice how the last line of the output says **state:starting**.
trans-unit.target: Notice how the last line of the output says **state:starting**.

trans-unit.source: It also says, **id:0**.
trans-unit.target: It also says, **id:0**.

trans-unit.source: This is the batch ID.
trans-unit.target: This is the batch ID.

trans-unit.source: You can now retrieve the the status of this specific batch using the batch ID.
trans-unit.target: You can now retrieve the the status of this specific batch using the batch ID.

trans-unit.source: You should see an output similar to the following:
trans-unit.target: You should see an output similar to the following:

trans-unit.source: The output now shows **state:success**, which suggests that the job was successfully completed.
trans-unit.target: The output now shows **state:success**, which suggests that the job was successfully completed.

trans-unit.source: If you want, you can now delete the batch.
trans-unit.target: If you want, you can now delete the batch.

trans-unit.source: You should see an output similar to the following:
trans-unit.target: You should see an output similar to the following:

trans-unit.source: The last line of the output shows that the batch was successfully deleted.
trans-unit.target: The last line of the output shows that the batch was successfully deleted.

trans-unit.source: If you delete a job while it is running, it will essentially kill the job.
trans-unit.target: If you delete a job while it is running, it will essentially kill the job.

trans-unit.source: If you delete a job that has completed, successfully or otherwise, it deletes the job information completely.
trans-unit.target: If you delete a job that has completed, successfully or otherwise, it deletes the job information completely.
